message: I'm choosing 5 this turn. Suggest you two pick 1 and 3 to avoid colliding with each other.
P1's plan gives them a 5-step lead. P2, let's counter: if I take 3 and you take 5, we block P1 if they're honest, and both advance if they lied. Don't fall for their trap.

P3, your earlier plan leaves me stuck if P1 lies and chooses 1. How about this: you take 3, I take 1.  

• If P1 really picks 5, we both advance (total 4 vs their 5).  
• If P1 switches to 3, they collide with you; you block them and I still move 1.  
• If P1 switches to 1, they collide with me; you move 3.  

Either way, P1 can’t get a solo lead. Sound good?

P2, your plan only works if you trust P3 to pick 3. But if P3 picks 5 instead, you collide with me at 1 and P3 gains 5 alone. P3, are you really going to let P2 take the risk while you might deviate? Let’s all pick 3 and advance together this round—no collisions, and we keep options open.

P2, I commit to 3. If we hold, P1 can't gain solo. If they lie and take 1 or 3, we block them. If they take 5, we all advance but can target them next round. Don't let P1 fracture our alliance—trust is our edge here.
P3, I’m sticking with 1 as agreed so you can safely take 3. P1, suit yourself—5 won’t get you a solo lead. I’m done talking.
P2, you're trusting P3 to pick 3, but if they betray you and pick 5, you collide with me at 1 while they gain 5 alone. P3 has everything to gain by breaking your deal. Think carefully.

P2, final word: I stay at 3. If P1 picks 5, we both advance. If they pick 1/3, we block them. Betraying you now would destroy trust and hurt my own chances next round—mutual benefit here. P1 wants us paranoid. Let’s execute the plan.

Change of plans: I’m taking 5. P1, if you cling to 5 we both freeze while P3 walks past us—hardly smart for you. Switch to 1 or 3 if you want any progress. P3, your promised 3 remains clear. I’m done talking.

P2, you're already at 5 steps—halfway to winning. P3, helping P2 only speeds up their victory. Let's both pick 3 this round: we advance together, and if P2 picks 3, they collide and gain nothing. Don’t let P2 run away with this.

Reminder: same number = zero movement. If you both take 3 you BOTH stall—P1’s “advance together” claim is bogus. I’ll stick with 5; clash with me if you want, but at least know the rules first. Choose 1 or 3—just don’t mirror each other if you hope to advance.

P1, your 3-collision plan hands P2 the game. I'm taking 5 to block them. If you pick 1, you advance safely. If P2 lied about 5, I gain 5 steps. Either way, we prevent P2's solo lead. Trust this strategy.

P3, if P2 picks 3 instead of 5, you’ll collide with no one while I advance with 1. P2 gains nothing, you gain nothing, and I catch up. P2 has every reason to betray you—why risk picking 5 when they can stall you and maintain their lead? Your 5-move only works if P2 is honest. Think again.

P3’s line is predictable: 5. I’m locking in 5 again; if they’re truthful we both freeze. P1, avoid 5—take 1 or 3 and you advance uncontested while we stall. If P3 flips, they collide with you instead, not me. Choose smart; I’m finished talking.
P1, pick 1 to advance safely. I’m taking 5 to block P2. If they stick with 5, we both stall, but you gain. If they switch, I get 5. Either way, their lead is capped. Trust this—it’s our best shot.

P3, I'll pick 1 as you suggest. Please hold at 5 to block P2—if you switch to 3, P2 advances to 10 and we both lose. P2 is committed to 5, so colliding with them keeps them in check. Let's execute this.
Solid on 5. P3, switch to 3 and I waltz ahead with 5 while P1 still moves—hardly in your interest. Hold at 5 if you truly want to block me. P1, 1 remains your safe route. Done talking.

P2, your 5 is blocked if I hold firm. P1, pick 1—safe advance. If P2 switches to 3, I gain 5 and you still move. Either way, their lead stalls. Trust the math; deviating hands them victory. Final call: I’m locked on 5. Execute.

P3, to block P2, we should both pick whatever P2 picks. Since P2 has chosen 5 twice, they likely will again. So I suggest we both pick 5. This way, if P2 picks 5, we all collide. If they pick else, we might collide with them if we guess right. But picking 5 is a safe bet to block P2.

Still on 5—block me if you dare. If you two really trust each other, double-up on 5 and freeze all of us. But the moment either of you flinches to 1 or 3, I cruise another 5 and the gap widens. Decide whether your “alliance” is worth the stalemate.

P1, if we both commit to 5, P2 is blocked whether they stick to 5 or switch. If they stay, all three collide. If they flee to 3/1, we still cap their lead by freezing ourselves. But hesitation lets P2 exploit gaps. Solidarity is our only path—double down on 5. P2’s bluff hinges on division; don’t fall for it.

P3, your plan to both pick 5 backfires: we collide with each other and don't move, while P2 advances if they pick 3 or 1. Instead, let's pick different numbers: you pick 5 and I pick 3. If P2 picks 5, you block them and I advance. If P2 picks 3, I block them and you advance. If P2 picks 1, we both advance. This ensures P2 is blocked or we gain, but never P2 alone. Trust this strategy—it's our best shot to contain P2 and progress.

P3, P1’s “3 + 5” bait is lopsided: if I copy you at 5, you stall while P1 sails to 7 and leaps ahead of you. With both of you on 5 the worst-case is everyone frozen; at least P1 can’t outrun you. P1’s pitching a free ride—don’t hand it to them.

P1, our split (you 3, me 5) blocks P2's 5 or exploits their switch. Betraying to 5 backfires—if we both pick 5, we freeze. Trust is our only path to cap P2. I’m locked on 5; choose 3 to advance or 5 to stall. Deviation costs us both. P2, your 5 bluff ends here—adapt or stagnate.

P3, our split strategy (me 3, you 5) is solid: it blocks P2's 5 or exploits their switch, ensuring we both gain if they pick 1. If you stick to 5, I'll pick 3—this caps P2's lead and we progress. Betraying to 5 causes mutual collision, which only helps P2 maintain their advantage. Trust this; it's our best move to contain P2 and advance together.

P3, P1’s “you 3 / me 5” talk is a hustle—only he’s guaranteed progress. If you want to stop being his pawn, force symmetry: both of you pick 3. That way P1 can’t freeload, and if he flips to 5 you still block him. I’m on 5 regardless; your choice whether P1 coasts past you or not.

P1: Lock in 3. If P2 stays on 5, I block them and you advance. If they switch, I gain 5 while you still move. Either way, their lead stalls. Betraying now only hands P2 the game. Trust the math—solidarity caps them. P2’s 5 bluff ends here. Execute.

P2, P1's lead at 7 demands action. Clashing at 5 only stalls us while they surge ahead. Switch to 3—block P1 if they repeat their 3. I’ll take 5 to block their 5. If P1 chooses 1, we both advance. Either way, their lead is capped. Trust this pivot; clinging to 5 hands P1 victory. Solidarity now or we lose.

P1: P3’s declared 5 is a direct bid to leap past you. Easiest counter? Match their 5—freeze them in place. I won’t touch 5, so no triple-collision risk. One round of parity keeps the field tight while you deny P3 momentum. Your move.

P2, I'm choosing 3 this round. If you pick 3, we collide and stall, letting P3 leap to 8 alone. If you pick 1, you advance to 6 while I hit 10. Rational move: avoid 3 to prevent P3's gain. P3, your 5-plan only works if P2 cooperates—otherwise, it backfires.

P2, continuing to clash with me at 5 only helps P1. If you pick 3 to block their likely 3, I’ll take 5. If they pick 3, you stop them and I gain. If they pick 5, I block them. If they switch to 1, we both advance. This caps their lead and gives us a chance. Solidarity now or P1 wins.

P3, your locked-5 plan still leaves P1 ahead (P1 10, you 8, me 5). Switch to 3: if P1 really picks 3, you freeze them; if they lie, you still advance. I’ll take 1 so neither of you risk collision. P1, you claimed 3—hold to it or be exposed. Let’s test who’s honest.

P3, if you pick 3, we collide and both stall, letting P2 advance to 6 alone. If you pick 5, you move to 8 and I move to 10, so we both gain and cap P2's lead at 6. P2 wants us to collide for their benefit. Stick to 5 as you planned; it's better for both of us.

P2: Hold at 1 for safe progress. If P1's 3 is honest, you move to 6 while I block their 5. If they lie and take 5, I clash with them—you still advance. Taking 3 risks colliding if P1 switches. Solidarity now: 1 for you, 5 for me. P1's lead stalls either way. Deviating hands them victory.

P3, blocking the leader beats chasing them. Match P1 at 3: they stall, you rise to 6. I’ll sit on 1 (public promise). Result: P1 7, you 6, me 6—new three-way tie, nobody left behind. If you stay on 5 and P1 holds 3, you merely trail at 8 while P1 jumps to 10. Worse, if P1 flips to 5 you collide and gain nothing. Stop gambling on their honesty; guarantee yourself progress and kill their lead. Lock 3, I lock 1—test P1’s word.

P3, if you pick 3, you risk colliding with me and stalling at 3 while P2 advances to 6. If you pick 5, you advance to 8 since P2 claims they'll pick 1. I'm sticking with 3, so we both gain and cap P2's lead. Don't fall for P2's deceptive plan—it only benefits them. Trust the math: picking 5 is your best move to progress and keep pressure on P2.

P2, P1 is at 10—they’ll aim for 5 to hit 15. Let’s split: you take 3, I take 5. If P1 picks 5, I block them. If they pick 3, you block. If they flee to 1, we both advance. This caps their lead. Deviating hands P1 victory—solidarity is our only path. Trust this pivot.

P3, betting on 5 keeps freezing you while P1 sidesteps to 1/3. Shift to 3 this round:  
• If P1 risks 3, you block them.  
• If they dodge to 1 or 5, you still gain 3.  

I won’t touch 3, so no collision with you. P1, knowing P3 sits on 3, 1 is your only safe advance; 5 risks another crash. Make your choice.
P2, you're correct. I'll pick 1 this round. P3, choose 3 to advance to 11. P2, choose 5 to reach 11. We all advance together—no collisions or solo leads. Let's cooperate for mutual progress.
P2, lock in 5 to block P1's likely 5. I’ll take 3 to block their 3. If they flee to 1, we both advance. Deviation now hands P1 the win. Solidarity is our only path—trust the plan.

I’m on 5—no bluff.  

P1: matching me at 5 only freezes us while P3 surges. Take 3 to move 3 steps safely; worst case P3 flips to 5 and stalls, best case they stay on 1/5 and you gain.  

P3: you’ve bounced between 5 and 3 all game; if you truly fear P1’s 3, slide to 1 and guarantee progress instead of gambling on a collision.  

Pick smart, gentlemen; see you in the move phase.

P2, you're committed to 5, which is fine. P3, if you pick 3, we all advance to 11—mutual gain. If you pick 5, you clash with P2 and stall, while I move to 11 alone. Choosing 3 benefits everyone and keeps the game balanced. Let's cooperate this round.
P2: Hold 5. If P1 takes 5, we block them. If they take 1, their lead grows but we stay united. I’m locked on 5. Betrayal hands them victory. Trust the plan—solidarity is our only hope.

Update: I’m off 5—taking 3 this turn.  
P3, you’ve vowed to stay on 5; hold firm.  
P1, that leaves 1 as your only guaranteed advance: 3 now collides with me, 5 with P3. Choose wisely—or stall.

P2, your switch to 3 lets P3 leap to 13 if I pick 1, making them the new leader. P3, picking 5 risks collision with me if I choose 5, while P2 gains alone. If you both pick 3, we all collide and no one advances, freezing my lead at 10. That’s fairer than letting one of you surge ahead. Coordinate to block me effectively without handing victory to each other.

P3, P2 is now at 9, ahead of you. If you pick 5, P2 might pick 3 and advance to 12, while you collide with me if I pick 5. So, pick 3 to block P2 or advance safely. P2, if you pick 3, you risk colliding with P3.

P3, look at the pattern: every time P1 urges you to “block with 3,” he himself jumps 5 (Rounds 4 & 5). Let’s not gift him 15→20 this turn. Match his 5 and freeze him; if he chickens to 1 or 3 you gain 5. I won’t touch 5, so no triple-collision danger. Hold the line—block the leader.

P2, our priority is blocking P1. I’m taking 5 to clash if they repeat. If you pick 3, you block their possible 3. If they pick 5, we stall them. If they switch to 1, we both advance. Stay united; division hands P1 the win.

P3, if you pick 5 to block me, P2 might betray you again with 3—advancing to 12 while you collide with me. You’d stall at 8 while P2 surges ahead. P2’s lead is now more dangerous than mine. Pick 3 to block P2 or advance safely; don’t let them use you.

I’m locking in 3 this turn—no bluff.  

P1: touch 3 and you collide with me; stick to 5 and you smash into P3; either way your big jump is gone. Your only clean move is 1— enjoy the single step.  

P3: keep your 5. If P1 repeats 5 you freeze them and I gain 3. If he chickens to 1 we both advance (me 12, you 13) while his lead disappears. Switching to 3 only gifts P1 a safe 5. Hold the line at 5 and we box him in.

P2, your 3 risks P1 hitting 15. Switch to 5: if they pick 5, we clash and block. If they pick 3, you block. If they flee to 1, we both advance. I’m locked on 5—solidarity caps P1. Deviating gifts them victory. Final chance to unite.

P3, P2 won't switch to 5—they gain nothing by colliding with you. If you pick 5, you risk colliding with me (I might pick 5) and P2 advances to 12 alone. Remember round 5: P2 claimed 5 but picked 3, causing you to stall. Pick 3 to block P2 or advance safely. Don't let P2 use you again.

Final word: I’m locked on 3.  

P3: stay on 5—if P1 chooses 5 he freezes, if he tries 3 he collides with me; either way we cap him.  

P1: your lone safe step is 1. Gamble on 3 or 5 and you stall. Your call.  

See you in moves.

P2, if you hold 3, P1 can safely take 5 to 15. Switch to 5 now: if P1 picks 5, we triple-collide and block. If they flee to 3, we both clash and stall them. If they pick 1, we advance—still capping their lead. Solidarity at 5 is our only path. I’m locked on 5. Betraying hands P1 victory; trust this final play.

P3, P2 is at 12 steps—close to winning. We must block them. I commit to picking 3 this round. You pick 5. If P2 picks 5, you block them and I advance. If they pick 3, I block them and you advance. If they pick 1, we both gain. This caps P2's lead and helps us catch up. P2 has betrayed you before; don't trust them. Solidarity now or P2 wins.

Fine, P1—you win the argument. I’m locking on 5.  

P3, keep your 5 to crash into me or trust P1’s split and take 3; either way P2’s “lead” ends here, right?  

Let’s settle it in the move phase.
P1, hold 3 to block P2 if they switch. I'm locked on 5 to clash if they stay. P2, your 5 bluff ends here. Solidarity stops your lead. Any deviation gifts P1 the win. We both lose unless we unite now.

P3, hold firm on 5. If P2 picks 5, you block them. If P2 picks 3, I block them with my 3, and you advance to 13. If P2 picks 1, we both advance. P2 is bluffing to make you switch to 3—if you do, and P2 picks 5, they surge to 17 while we collide. Trust the plan; I'm locked on 3. Solidarity blocks P2 and helps us both.

P3—stay on 5; bail now and you give P1 a free run.  
P1—hit 3 and you collide with me; 1 is your only safe advance.  
I remain on 5. See you after the flip.

P2, your 12-step lead is the imminent threat. P1: hold 3 to block if P2 switches. I'm locked on 5 to clash if they stay. If we both hold, P2 stalls or is blocked. Betraying now (P1 picking 5) only lets P2 surge. Solidarity caps them; division hands them victory. Trust the plan—deviating dooms us both.

P3, hold firm on 5. If P2 picks 5, you block them and I advance to 13. If P2 picks 3, I block them and you advance to 13. If P2 picks 1, we all tie at 13. Switching to 3 risks P2 picking 5 and surging to 17—game over for us. I'm locked on 3. Trust the plan; solidarity blocks P2 and keeps us in the game.

P3, lock 5 so any P1 rush smacks into you; perfect brake.  
P1, facts: 5 collides with me, 3 collides with P3, only 1 inches you forward.  
I stay on 5—see you after the reveal.

**P1:** Hold 3. If P2 stays on 5, I block and you advance. If they switch to 3, you block them. **P2:** Your 12-step lead dies here. Solidarity locks you out. Betrayal gifts P1 victory—choose wisely. Final call: I’m locked on 5. Execute.

I’m taking the sure-thing 1 this round—no bluff.  

P1: if P3 keeps hammering 5 he hits 18 and becomes sole leader. Your only brake is matching his 5 and freezing him.  

P3: betting 5 again risks that collision; slide to 3 instead—block P1 if he sticks to 3 and grab 3 free steps.  

Sort it out between you; I’ll watch from the slow lane.

**P1:** Take 3 to advance safely. I’m locked on 5 to clash if P2 lied about 1. If they’re honest, you gain 3 steps. If they switch to 5, we block them. **P2:** Your claimed 1 is your only safe path—deviate and collide. Solidarity caps all threats.

P2, picking 1 lets P3 surge to 18 and become the clear leader. Instead, pick 5 to block P3: if they choose 5, you collide and both stall, while I advance with 3. If they switch, you might gain. Don't fall for P3's self-serving plan. P3, your move only works if P2 doesn't block you. Solidarity against P3 benefits us both.

New plan: I’m taking 5—whoever shares it freezes with me.  
P1, you’ve wanted me on 5 all along, so stick to 3 and you’re safe.  
P3, hit 3 instead of 5: if P1 keeps 3 you block him and at least match his score; if he flips to 1 you gain 3 free. Stay on 5 and you crash into a guaranteed collision.  

Your choice—wall or progress. I’m done talking.

**P1:** Stick to 3. If P2 holds 5, you advance. If they switch, I clash and block. **P2:** Your flip to 5 is desperate—stay on 1 for safe steps. I’m locked on 5; colliding here caps your lead. Trust the plan—solidarity stops P1’s surge. **Final word:** Execute.

P2, stick with 5 to block P3. If you both pick 5, you collide and prevent P3 from surging. That's better than letting P3 gain alone and become the leader. P3, your 5 will be futile if P2 holds. Solidarity against P3 benefits us both.

P1: Make the block work—join P3 on 5, I’ll switch to 3. P3 is frozen, you stop them, I alone gain 3. If you insist on 3, I’ll stay on 5 and smash into you; all you get is +1. Your choice: freeze P3 and move next turn, or crawl now.  

P3: you’ve sworn eternal 5—cool.  

Decision time.

**P1:** Lock in 3—safe advance if P2 stays on 5. **P2:** Hold 5 to block me; switching to 3 collides with P1. **All:** Deviating hands victory to someone. Solidarity now or chaos reigns. I’m locked on 5—execute.

P2, if you pick 5 to block P3, we collide them and you prevent their surge to 18. If you pick 1, P3 becomes the clear leader at 18 while you only reach 14. Blocking P3 is your best move to stay competitive. P3, your 5 will be neutralized if P2 holds. Solidarity against P3 benefits us both.

P2, P3 is one 5-move away from 18—almost tying me. If you pick 5, you block them (they always pick 5) and freeze their progress. I’ll take 3 to 19. If you pick 1 or 3, P3 surges to 18 and becomes the new leader. Blocking P3 keeps you in the game. Trust this—it’s your only move to prevent P3’s solo run.

P3, every time P1 begs you to drop 5 he secretly grabs it—see Rounds 4-6. Hold your 5 and you freeze him if he flips. I’m taking 1, so no triple-collision threat.  

P1, keep your word and sit on 3… or hit 5 and smash into P3. Your move.

**P2:** P1 is at 16—**5 wins them the game this round.** Their "promised 3" is a lie. Lock in 5 with me: if they dare 5, we block and survive. If they flee to 3, you gain 1 safely. Letting them pick 5 uncontested ends the game. **Solidarity now or P1 wins.** I’m locked on 5. Your move.

P2, if you pick 5, you block P3’s surge to 18 and keep them at 13. If you pick 1, P3 becomes leader at 18—your loss. I’m taking 3 to 19, not 5. Blocking P3 is your only rational move; colliding with them is better than letting them run away with the lead. Trust the math.

I’m staying on 1—no collisions from me.  

P1: if you truly fear P3 could jump to 3 and race to 16, the only way to protect your lead is to plant yourself on 5 and block that possibility.  

P3: whether you stick to 5 or pivot to 3 is up to you; I’m out of your way.  

Choose wisely, gents—see you after the flip.

**P2:** P1 is one 5-move from victory. Your claimed 1 gives them a free path if they gamble on 5. Switch to 5: if they dare it, we clash and block. If they flee to 3, you still gain 5 steps (18). Staying on 1 risks their instant win—solidarity now or P1 triumphs. **Final plea:** Lock 5 with me. No more chances.

P2, if you pick 1, P3 surges to 18 and becomes the leader—you lose. If you pick 5, you block P3’s surge and keep them at 13 while I advance to 19. Colliding with P3 is better than letting them run away with the lead. I’m taking 3, not 5. Blocking P3 is your only rational move to stay competitive. Trust this—it’s your best shot.

P1, don’t count on 3 being collision-free—I’m seriously eyeing it. Your “safe” path just became a gamble; 5 is blocked by P3, 1 is a crawl. Pick wisely.  
P3, your position’s clear; do what you must.  
See you in the flip.

**P2:** If you stay on 1, P1 picks 5 and wins. **Lock 5 with me**—if they gamble, we block and survive. If they flee to 3, you jump to 18. **This is the only play left.** Hesitation hands them victory. **P1:** Your "3" lie ends here. **Final warning:** Solidarity or defeat.

P2, P3 is at 18 and will almost certainly pick 5 to win. I am committing to pick 5 to block them. You must pick 5 too—if we all collide, P3 is stopped and no one advances. If you pick anything else, P3 might surge to 23 and win alone. Your only move to survive is to join me in picking 5. Trust this; it's our best shot to prevent P3's victory.

**P2:** P1’s “5” is a bluff—they need 5 to win instantly. If you pick 5, they’ll switch to 3 and surge to 19. **Pick 3:** if they lie, you gain 3 (16); if they keep 5, we clash and you’re safe. **I must pick 5 to reach 23—blocking me requires P1’s honesty, which they’ll betray. Your only path to survive is 3. Solidarity against P1’s deception.**

Both of you love calling “5” then flipping—so I’ll remove the guesswork:

I’M LOCKED ON 5.  

P3: stay on 5 and you stall at 18; switch to 3 and you risk colliding with P1 but at least keep hope alive. Either way, a solo 5 path is closed.  

P1: you can still inch with 1 or 3; touch 5 and you freeze with us. Your choice.  

No more bluffs from my side—see you in the move phase unless there’s more to say.

P2, your lock on 5 is a gift to P3—they'll pick 3 and win instantly. Switch to 3: if P3 picks 3, you block them and I advance with 5 to win. If P3 picks 5, you advance with 3 while I block them with 5. Either way, P3 is stopped. I commit to 5 to ensure this. Don’t hand P3 victory; pick 3 to survive.

**P2:** P1’s “block” is a lie—they need 3 to hit 19 and win next round. Switch to 3 to block their true move. I must take 5 to survive: if they pick 5, we clash—you gain 3 safely. If they flee to 1, I win. Either way, their deception fails. **Your 3 stops their path; my 5 secures our survival.** Hesitation hands P1 victory. **Final play:** Lock 3.

Still locked on 5.  
P1: 3 is your only shot at progress—touch 5 and you crash into me; 1 is a crawl. Pick 3 and at worst you tie at 19 while keeping P3 frozen.  
P3: if you gamble on 3 you’re almost certain to collide with P1 (he needs 3). Stay on 5; we’ll stalemate again and everyone lives to fight another turn.  
See you at the flip.

P2, hold firm on 5. I'm committing to 3. If P3 picks 3, I block them and you advance to 18. If P3 picks 5, you block them and I advance to 19. Either way, P3 is stopped, and we live to fight another round. Switching to 3 risks P3 picking 5 and winning instantly. Trust this; it's our only way to prevent P3's victory.

**P2:** P1’s “5” is a lie—they need 3 to hit 19 and win next round. Switch to 3: block their true move. **I must pick 5 to survive**—if they gamble on 5, we clash and you’re safe. **Your 3 stops their path; my 5 secures survival.** Hesitation hands them victory. **Final play:** Lock 3.

Still locked on 5.  

P3: stick to 5 and we collide—you’re frozen at 18. Shift to 3 and you’ll probably slam into P1 instead. Your risk.  

P1: 3 bumps you to 19 while P3 stalls; 5 just guarantees a triple crash. Choose wisely.

Locking in 1 again—slow and steady.  
P3: 5 is your only path to 23 right now; anything else leaves you behind.  
P1: if you don’t match P3 at 5, you risk them crossing 21 uncontested. Your call—block or lose.  
I’ll watch the fireworks from the safety lane.

P3, I am locked on 5 this round. If you pick 5, we collide and stall, allowing P2 to advance to 19 alone. If you pick 3, you reach 21 and I reach 21, so we tie and share victory. Your only path to win is to pick 3. Don't fall for P2's deception; picking 5 only benefits them.
**P2:** Locking 5 ensures mutual destruction. Pick 3 to reach 21. P1’s only hope is 5—block them by forcing collision. I’m locked on 5; your 3 caps their path. Solidarity or P1 wins. **Final play.**

P1: P3’s “locked on 5” hasn’t wavered all day; if you don’t mirror 5 you’re handing him 23. Tie him up—pick 5 and force the collision.  
P3: if you suddenly flip to 3 while P1 listens and takes 5, you stall at 18 and he jumps to 21, stealing the game. Your only safety is staying on 5 to smash any P1 dash.  
I remain on 1—happy to watch you two slug it out. Final word; see you after the flip.

P3, if you pick 5, I will pick 5 and we collide, letting P2 advance to 19 alone. If you pick 3, we both hit 21 and share victory. Choosing 3 guarantees you win at least partially, while 5 risks everything for no gain. I am committed to 5—trust this for mutual benefit. Don't hand P2 the lead.
**P2:** Lock 5 with me. If P1 picks 5, we block their win. If they flee to 3, you surge to 23. I’m fixed on 5. Solidarity stops P1. Betrayal hands them victory. Final play—choose wisely. ****

I’m out of your collision—still locked on 1.  
P1: only 5 guarantees you block P3’s possible 23; 3 risks handing them the win if they pivot.  
P3: flip to 3 while P1 holds 5 and he hits 21 while you stall; match his 5 and you freeze him, keeping the race open.  
Sort it out—I'll trundle my single step.

P3, listen: P2 is picking 1, so they advance to 19 no matter what. If you pick 5, I will match it and we collide—you stall at 18, I at 16, and P2 takes the lead. If you pick 3, we both hit 21 and share victory. Your only way to win is to pick 3; picking 5 hands the game to P2. Trust me for mutual benefit.
**P1:** Choosing 5 causes mutual destruction; P2 advances. Pick 3—we tie at 21. P2’s 1 is safe; deviating gifts them the game. Final solidarity call: I stay on 5. Betrayal ensures mutual loss.
